sentences.sContent: I allowed the two pennies to fall against the sixpence in my pocket.
sentences.sContent_eng: I allowed the two pennies to fall against the sixpence in my pocket.
sentences.sCn: 我把口袋里的两个便士跟六便士撞在一块。

sentences.sContent: The sherry went to my head and I was im- poverished for days by the loss of sixpence.
sentences.sContent_eng: The sherry went to my head and I was im- poverished for days by the loss of sixpence.
sentences.sCn: 六便士的酒钱落到我头上，接下来几天我几乎身无分文。 这里的女主人叫艾伦?

sentences.sContent: In 1749 some 12, 000 people paid two shillings sixpence each to hear Handel’s 100-piece band rehearse his Royal Fireworks Music at Vauxhall Gardens(Forsyth, 1985).
sentences.sContent_eng: In 1749 some 12, 000 people paid two shillings sixpence each to hear Handel’s 100-piece band rehearse his Royal Fireworks Music at Vauxhall Gardens(Forsyth, 1985).
sentences.sCn: 大约1.2万人在1749年支付了两先令六便士，聆听了亨德尔在沃克斯霍尔园林的皇家烟火音乐的100人排练(福塞斯，1985)。

words.tran: 六便士一本的书；电影院的六便士座位；六便士硬币

trans.tranOther: a small silver-coloured coin worth six old  pennies  , used in Britain in the past
